questions.text: A person presented with diarrhoea, dementia dermatitis (typical castle neck appearance 24 hour urinary HIAA increased)this patient may have:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Carcinoid syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The increased urinary HIAA is a hallmark of carcinoid syndrome . This condition arises from excessive serotonin production, which leads to pellagra-like symptoms (diarrhoea, dementia, dermatitis) due to a diversion of tryptophan from niacin synthesis to serotonin production.
  • ➤ increased urinary HIAA
  • ➤ carcinoid syndrome
  • ➤ pellagra-like symptoms

questions.text: Obligate Allosteric activator of rate limiting CPS-1 of urea cycle is ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) N-acetyl glutamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The obligate allosteric activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS-1) , the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle, is N-acetyl glutamate (NAG) . Without NAG, CPS-1 cannot be activated to begin the urea cycle, which is crucial for detoxifying ammonia in the liver.
  • ➤ obligate allosteric activator
  • ➤ carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS-1)
  • ➤ N-acetyl glutamate (NAG)

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate with complete hypotonia, convulsions, failure to thrive and metabolic acidosis. The baby has smell of burnt sugar in urine. The test called DNPH test is positive. What is the enzyme deficiency in this metabolic disorder?
questions.correct_answer: C. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enzyme deficiency responsible for Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase . This enzyme is crucial for the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine), and its deficiency leads to the accumulation of branched-chain keto acids in the blood and urine, causing neurological symptoms and the characteristic burnt sugar smell in the urine.
  • ➤ Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD)
  • ➤ branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • ➤ branched-chain amino acids
  • ➤ branched-chain keto acids
  • ➤ burnt sugar smell

questions.text: Malate Aspartate shuttle is required for ​​​​​​​

options.label: A
options.text: Transport of NADH from Cytosol to Mitochondria

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Malate-Aspartate shuttle is involved in transferring NADH across the mitochondrial membrane and plays an essential role in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis .
  • ➤ Malate-Aspartate shuttle
  • ➤ glycolysis
  • ➤ gluconeogenesis

questions.text: Select the one of the following statements that is not correct

options.label: A
options.text: The side-chains of the amino acids cysteine and methionine absorb light at 280 nm.

options.label: B
options.text: Glycine is often present in regions where a polypeptide forms a sharp bend, reversing the direction of a polypeptide.

options.label: C
options.text: The C, N, O, and H atoms of a peptide bond are coplanar.

options.label: D
options.text: A linear pentapeptide contains four peptide bonds.

questions.correct_answer: A. The side-chains of the amino acids cysteine and methionine absorb light at 280 nm.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The side-chains of the amino acids cysteine and methionine absorb light at 280 nm.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As cysteine and methionine do not absorb light at 280 nm, unlike aromatic amino acids.

questions.text: Which of the following is a powerful qualitative and quantitative technique to assess molecular mass and primary amino acid sequence of peptides and proteins?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mass spectrometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The techniques used for determining the molecular mass and primary amino acid sequence of peptides and proteins, with a focus on mass spectrometry as the most powerful and versatile tool for this purpose. To provide insight into the practical uses of mass spectrometry in proteomics, such as identifying protein sequences , post-translational modifications , and molecular weight , which are essential for a deeper understanding of protein function and structure.
  • ➤ The techniques used for determining the molecular mass and primary amino acid sequence of peptides and proteins, with a focus on mass spectrometry as the most powerful and versatile tool for this purpose.
  • ➤ techniques
  • ➤ molecular mass
  • ➤ primary amino acid sequence
  • ➤ To provide insight into the practical uses of mass spectrometry in proteomics, such as identifying protein sequences , post-translational modifications , and molecular weight , which are essential for a deeper understanding of protein function and structure.
  • ➤ uses of mass spectrometry
  • ➤ protein sequences
  • ➤ post-translational modifications
  • ➤ molecular weight

questions.text: Select the one of the following statements that is not correct.

options.label: A
options.text: Protein folding is assisted by intervention of specialized auxiliary proteins called chaperones.

options.label: B
options.text: Protein acquire function at tertiary level and can be detected by Cryo-Electron Microscopy.

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of S-S bonds in a mature protein is facilitated by the enzyme protein disulfide isomerase.

options.label: D
options.text: Only a few unusual proteins, such as collagen, require posttranslational processing by partial proteolysis to attain their mature conformation.

questions.correct_answer: D. Only a few unusual proteins, such as collagen, require posttranslational processing by partial proteolysis to attain their mature conformation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Only a few unusual proteins, such as collagen, require posttranslational processing by partial proteolysis to attain their mature conformation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Collagen does not require partial proteolysis for maturation, but undergoes modifications like hydroxylation, facilitated by vitamin C.

questions.text: Parents bring in their 2-week-old child fearful that he has ingested a poison. They had delayed disposing one of the child’s diapers, and noted a black discoloration where the urine had collected. Later, they realized that all of the child’s diapers would turn black if stored as waste for a day or so. Knowing that phenol groups can complex to form colors, which amino acid pathways are implicated in this phenomenon? ​​​​​​​

options.label: A
options.text: The phenylalanine, tyrosine, and homogentisate pathway

options.label: C
options.text: The leucine, isoleucine, and valine pathway

questions.correct_answer: A. The phenylalanine, tyrosine, and homogentisate pathway
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The phenylalanine, tyrosine, and homogentisate pathway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Black discoloration of urine can be due to a defect in the phenylalanine and tyrosine metabolic pathway, specifically a condition called alkaptonuria, which involves the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant, is brought to the pediatric clinic by her concerned parents with history of generalized fits. Baby had delayed milestone and was lethargic, hair was grey colored and skin was light colored. Mother gave the history of mousy odor in the urine. On IQ assessment patient has intellectual disability. In one of the following rare variants of PKU The enzyme deficient is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dihydro pterin Reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A rare variant of PKU involves a deficiency in the enzyme Dihydropterin Reductase, which impairs the regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), affecting the activity of phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.text: A biochemist is doing experiment on a protein to determine the amino acid sequence, while experiment mutation occurred and mutated protein acquired Decreased tendency to be phosphorylated in this protein replaced amino acid is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asparagine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amino acids with hydroxyl groups (serine, threonine, and tyrosine) are phosphorylated. Replacing one of these with asparagine (which lacks a hydroxyl group) would decrease the protein’s tendency to be phosphorylated .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect pair of amino acid and product
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Histidine: GABA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histidine is converted to histamine, not GABA. GABA is derived from glutamate, not histidine.

questions.text: Select the correct answer: The first reaction in the degradation of most of the protein amino acids involves the participation of
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pyridoxal phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cofactor required for the first reaction in the degradation of most amino acids (transamination) is pyridoxal phosphate (the active form of vitamin B6).

questions.text: Identify the amino acid that is the major contributor to the transport of nitrogen destined for excretion as urea:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glutamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glutamine is the primary amino acid responsible for transporting nitrogen to the liver for urea excretion.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme can use both NAD and NADP
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glutamate dehydrogenase can use both NAD and NADP as cofactors, generating either NADH or NADPH.

questions.text: In Hyper Ammonia Type I there is increase ammonia due to deficiency of CPS-I, ammonia is toxic to brain by decreasing the following substrate of TCA cycle:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) α-Ketoglutarate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ammonia in Hyperammonemia Type I is toxic to the brain primarily by decreasing the levels of α-ketoglutarate in the TCA cycle, impairing energy production and leading to encephalopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Valine replaced by leucine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The conservative mutation (such as replacing one branched-chain amino acid with another of similar properties) is the least likely to disrupt protein function. In this case, valine replaced by leucine (option A) is the correct answer.
  • ➤ conservative mutation
  • ➤ valine replaced by leucine

questions.text: Sulfhydryl group containing amino acid(s)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The amino acid that contains a sulfhydryl group (—SH) is cysteine (option B). It is crucial in protein structure as it forms disulfide bonds that stabilize the tertiary and quaternary structures of proteins.
  • ➤ sulfhydryl group
  • ➤ cysteine

questions.text: 26 year old male with colicky pain and the crystals in urine as shown in image below. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cystinuria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystinuria is characterized by the presence of hexagonal cysteine crystals in the urine and the abnormal excretion of cysteine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine (mnemonic: COLA).

questions.text: The vitamin that acts as a coenzyme of the given reaction is Serine + Homocysteine → Cystathionine + H₂O
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin B6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate) is the coenzyme required for the reaction converting serine and homocysteine to cystathionine in the transsulfuration pathway.
  • ➤ Vitamin B6

questions.text: Ingestion of benzoic acid in man result in an increase in urinary?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hippuric acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ingestion of benzoic acid leads to an increase in urinary hippuric acid , as it is conjugated with glycine in the liver and excreted through the kidneys.
  • ➤ Ingestion of benzoic acid leads to an increase in urinary hippuric acid

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid will migrate slowest to the anode end on electrophoresis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lysine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lysine migrates the slowest towards the anode in electrophoresis due to its positive charge and high pKa value, causing it to remain more neutral in the electrophoresis medium.

questions.text: As one molecule of NADH is oxidized via the respiratory chain:

options.label: A
options.text: 1.5 molecules of ATP are produced in total.

options.label: B
options.text: 1 molecule of ATP is produced as electrons pass through complex IV.

options.label: C
options.text: 1 molecule of ATP is produced as electrons pass through complex II.

options.label: D
options.text: 1 molecule of ATP is produced as electrons pass through complex III.

questions.correct_answer: D. 1 molecule of ATP is produced as electrons pass through complex III.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 molecule of ATP is produced as electrons pass through complex III.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complex III contributes significantly to ATP production by generating a proton gradient, but it does not directly produce ATP. The ATP is synthesized by ATP synthase , which uses the proton gradient generated by complexes I, III, and IV.
  • ➤ Complex III
  • ➤ ATP synthase

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is seen by an ophthalmologist for vision difficulties, and the physician notices a slowing of the boy's eye movements. The ophthalmologist finds ophthalmoplegia and pigmentary retinopathy and suspects the child has Kearns-Sayre syndrome. Assuming that the defect in this disorder is due to a mutation in complex II of the ETC, electron transfer from which substrate would be impaired?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Succinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Succinate is the correct substrate because it directly enters Complex II (succinate dehydrogenase), which is responsible for transferring electrons from succinate to ubiquinone in the electron transport chain.
  • ➤ Succinate
  • ➤ Complex II

questions.text: A student takes some tablets she is offered at a disco, and without asking what they are she swallows them. A short time later she starts to hyperventilate and becomes very hot. What is the most likely action of the tablets she has taken?

options.label: A
options.text: An inhibitor of mitochondrial ATP synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: An inhibitor of the transport of ADP into mitochondria to be phosphorylated

options.label: C
options.text: An inhibitor of the transport of ATP out of mitochondria into the cytosol

options.label: D
options.text: An uncoupler of mitochondrial electron transport and oxidative phosphorylation

questions.correct_answer: D. An uncoupler of mitochondrial electron transport and oxidative phosphorylation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) An uncoupler of mitochondrial electron transport and oxidative phosphorylation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uncoupling agents , such as 2,4-dinitrophenol , disrupt the proton gradient in mitochondria, causing heat production instead of ATP synthesis, which is what is likely happening in this case.
  • ➤ Uncoupling agents
  • ➤ 2,4-dinitrophenol

questions.text: The flow of electrons through the respiratory chain and the production of ATP are normally tightly coupled. The processes are uncoupled by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thermogenin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thermogenin is the only option listed here that uncouples electron transport from ATP synthesis by creating a proton leak, allowing energy to be released as heat. This process is important for thermoregulation in certain tissues.
  • ➤ Thermogenin
  • ➤ uncouples

questions.text: A blood sample is taken from a 50-year-old woman after an overnight fast. Which one of the following will be at a higher concentration than after she had eaten a meal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nonesterified fatty acids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the fasting state, nonesterified fatty acids (NEFAs) will be at a higher concentration in the blood due to the breakdown of stored triacylglycerol in adipose tissue. This is in contrast to the postprandial (after-meal) state, where insulin promotes fat storage, and fatty acids are generally lower in the bloodstream.
  • ➤ nonesterified fatty acids (NEFAs)
  • ➤ triacylglycerol

questions.text: Which one of following statements about the fed and fasting metabolic states is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: In the fasting state glucagon acts to increase the activity of lipoprotein lipase in adipose tissue.

options.label: B
options.text: In the fasting state, glucagon acts to increase the synthesis of glycogen from glucose.

options.label: C
options.text: In the fed state insulin acts to increase the breakdown of glycogen to maintain blood glucose.

options.label: D
options.text: Ketone bodies are synthesized in liver in the fasting state, and the amount synthesized increases as fasting extends into starvation.

questions.correct_answer: D. Ketone bodies are synthesized in liver in the fasting state, and the amount synthesized increases as fasting extends into starvation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ketone bodies are synthesized in liver in the fasting state, and the amount synthesized increases as fasting extends into starvation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the fasting state, ketone bodies are produced in the liver, and their production increases as the fasting period extends into starvation. This is a key adaptation for energy production when glucose availability is limited.
  • ➤ In the fasting state, ketone bodies are produced in the liver, and their production increases as the fasting period extends into starvation.

questions.text: Which one of following statements about glycolysis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: All the reactions of glycolysis are freely reversible for gluconeogenesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Glycolysis can proceed in the absence of oxygen only if pyruvate is formed from lactate in muscle.

options.label: C
options.text: Red blood cells only metabolize glucose by anaerobic glycolysis (and the pentose phosphate pathway).

options.label: D
options.text: The reverse of glycolysis is the pathway for gluconeogenesis in skeletal muscle.

questions.correct_answer: C. Red blood cells only metabolize glucose by anaerobic glycolysis (and the pentose phosphate pathway).
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Red blood cells only metabolize glucose by anaerobic glycolysis (and the pentose phosphate pathway).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Red blood cells exclusively rely on anaerobic glycolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway for metabolism, as they lack mitochondria and cannot perform oxidative phosphorylation.

questions.text: A patient is in septic shock, and his tissues are poorly perfused and oxygenated. The major end product of glucose metabolism in these tissues will be an accumulation of which one of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lactate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In conditions of poor tissue perfusion and oxygenation (e.g., septic shock), anaerobic glycolysis predominates, and the major end product of glucose metabolism is lactate.

questions.text: All are used in gluconeogenesis except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oleate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oleate (a fatty acid) cannot be used for gluconeogenesis, while amino acids (except leucine and lysine) and certain citric acid cycle intermediates (such as succinate) can contribute to glucose production

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency room after having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The child has a history of epilepsy, ataxia, and lactic acidosis. When questioned, the parents state that their child was born with a rare metabolic disease, pyruvate carboxylase deficiency. Which one of the following metabolites is this child unable to produce effectively?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Oxaloacetate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pyruvate carboxylase deficiency, the child is unable to produce oxaloacetate effectively, leading to impaired gluconeogenesis and disruption of the citric acid cycle.

questions.text: A young man entered his physician's office complaining of bloating and diarrhea. His eyes were sunken, and the physician noted additional signs of dehydration. The patient's temperature was normal. He explained that the episode had occurred following a birthday party at which he had participated in an ice cream-eating contest. The patient reported prior episodes of a similar nature following ingestion of a significant amount of dairy products. This clinical picture is most probably due to a deficiency in the activity of: ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lactase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lactose intolerance is caused by a deficiency in lactase, an enzyme that breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose. When lactase is deficient, undigested lactose is fermented in the large intestine, causing bloating, diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort.

questions.text: A 10-month-old girl has been a fussy eater since being weaned, particularly when fruit is part of her diet. She would get cranky, sweat, and display dizziness, and lethargy, after eating a meal with fruit. Her mother noticed this correlation, and as long as fruit was withdrawn from her diet, the child did not display such symptoms. The problems the girl exhibits when eating fruit is most likely due to which one of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aldolase B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) is caused by a deficiency in aldolase B, leading to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate after fructose ingestion, which inhibits glycogen breakdown and causes symptoms such as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and lethargy, particularly after consuming fruit.

questions.text: Pyruvate can be a substrate for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyruvate can be converted into acetyl-CoA, which is a substrate for the TCA cycle, fatty acid synthesis, and cholesterol synthesis, especially in the fed state when energy is abundant and insulin levels are high.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with breast cancer presents with confusion, headaches, and persistent nausea. To evaluate for metastases to the brain, the oncologist orders a positron emission tomography (PET) scan, which covalently links a radioactive isotope to glucose and reveals highly active areas in the body (e.g., a tumor). Which of the following proteins enables the tracer to remain in the cell?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hexokinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hexokinase converts glucose to glucose-6-phosphate inside the cell, trapping it and preventing it from exiting the cell, which is crucial for enabling the radioactive glucose tracer to accumulate in highly metabolically active areas during a PET scan.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant, who was experiencing seizures, was diagnosed with a GLUT1 deficiency, resulting in reduced glucose uptake into the brain. As a result, which one of the following substrates was providing energy for the brain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ketone bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In GLUT1 deficiency, where glucose uptake into the brain is impaired, the brain compensates by using ketone bodies as an alternative fuel source for energy.
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Additional information:

questions.text: All of the following metabolic pathways occur in both Cytoplasm and Mitochondria, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glycolysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycolysis occurs exclusively in the cytoplasm, while heme synthesis, the urea cycle, and gluconeogenesis occur in both the cytoplasm and mitochondria.

questions.text: A newborn is found to have fasting hypoglycemia. The nursery staff begins overnight feeds by nasogastric tube because they find that the child has consistently low blood sugars. A liver biopsy and molecular studies demonstrate an absence of glycogen synthase. The normal function of this enzyme is to do which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Remove glucose residues one at a time from glycogen in the liver

options.label: B
options.text: Remove glucose residues one at a time from glycogen in muscles

options.label: C
options.text: Transfer glucose from UDP-glucose to the nonreducing end of a glycogen primer

questions.correct_answer: C. Transfer glucose from UDP-glucose to the nonreducing end of a glycogen primer
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Transfer glucose from UDP-glucose to the nonreducing end of a glycogen primer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen synthase is responsible for transferring glucose from UDP-glucose to the nonreducing end of a glycogen primer, facilitating the elongation of glycogen chains.

questions.text: A sprinter is trying to optimize his performance. He has calculated that, even under anaerobic conditions, his glycogen stores will supply him with enough energy to last the race. What would the energy difference be between using glucose from a dietary source versus relying solely on glucose from glycogen stores as fuel for his race?

options.label: A
options.text: Dietary would give 1 more mole of ATP/glucose

options.label: B
options.text: Dietary would give 2 more moles of ATP/ glucose

options.label: C
options.text: Dietary would give the same ATP/glucose

options.label: D
options.text: Dietary would give 1 less mole of ATP/ glucose

questions.correct_answer: D. Dietary would give 1 less mole of ATP/ glucose
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dietary would give 1 less mole of ATP/ glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dietary glucose generates 1 less mole of ATP compared to glycogen because dietary glucose requires 1 ATP for phosphorylation by hexokinase, while glycogen bypasses this step.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the pediatrician for failure to thrive. A workup including an ultrasound of his liver shows cirrhosis. A biopsy of the liver demonstrates a deficiency of glucosyl 4:6 transferase. Which of the following is the most likely glycogen storage disease (GSD) that affects this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type IV: Andersen disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Andersen disease (Type IV) is characterized by a deficiency of the branching enzyme (glucosyl 4:6 transferase) , leading to poorly branched glycogen, cirrhosis, and failure to thrive.
  • ➤ Andersen disease (Type IV)
  • ➤ branching enzyme (glucosyl 4:6 transferase)

questions.text: A four-year-old child with exercise intolerance. On investigation Blood pH 7.3, FBS 60mg%, hypertriglyceridemia, ketosis and lactic acidosis. The child had hepatomegaly and renomegaly. Biopsy of liver and kidney showed increased glycogen content. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Von Gierke's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Gierke's disease (Type I GSD) is characterized by glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency , leading to impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis , which results in severe hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, lactic acidosis , and hepatomegaly/renomegaly .
  • ➤ Von Gierke's disease (Type I GSD)
  • ➤ glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency
  • ➤ impaired glycogenolysis
  • ➤ gluconeogenesis
  • ➤ severe hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, lactic acidosis
  • ➤ hepatomegaly/renomegaly

questions.text: A 22-year-old soldier collapses from dehydration during maneuvers in the desert and is sent to a military hospital. Prior to enlisting, a physician observed a high level of glucose in his urine during an examination. At first, he was not allowed to enlist because he was suspected of having diabetes. However, further tests determined that his insulin level was normal. A glucose tolerance test exhibited a normal pattern. Laboratory tests following his dehydration episode repeat the previous findings, but further testing of the urine reveals that only d-glucose is elevated. Other sugars were not elevated. This patient's elevated urinary glucose and his dehydration episode are caused by a deficiency in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) SGLT 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SGLT2 deficiency results in renal glycosuria , where glucose is excreted in the urine despite normal blood glucose levels, because glucose reabsorption in the kidneys is impaired. This condition does not affect the normal glucose metabolism pathways in the body, leading to normal insulin levels and glucose tolerance.
  • ➤ SGLT2 deficiency
  • ➤ renal glycosuria

questions.text: Which GLUT transporter facilitates Fructose absorption along the apical side of enterocyte?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GLUT 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GLUT 5 is the primary transporter responsible for the absorption of fructose across the apical membrane of the enterocytes in the small intestine.
  • ➤ GLUT 5
  • ➤ absorption of fructose
  • ➤ apical membrane
  • ➤ enterocytes

questions.text: Patients with diabetes frequently report changing visual acuities when their glucose levels are chronically high. Which of the following could explain the fluctuating acuity with high blood glucose levels?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased oxidative phosphorylation in the lens

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased sorbitol in the lens
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased sorbitol in the lens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sorbitol accumulation in the lens due to the polyol pathway is the main cause of fluctuating visual acuity in patients with chronic high blood glucose levels in diabetes .
  • ➤ Sorbitol accumulation in the lens due to the polyol pathway is the main cause of fluctuating visual acuity in patients with chronic high blood glucose levels in diabetes .
  • ➤ Sorbitol accumulation
  • ➤ polyol pathway
  • ➤ fluctuating visual acuity
  • ➤ chronic high blood glucose levels
  • ➤ diabetes

questions.text: Which of the following is not a reducing sugar -
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sucrose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sucrose is the only non-reducing sugar among the options because both of its anomeric carbons are involved in the glycosidic bond, leaving no free reducing group.
  • ➤ Sucrose is the only non-reducing sugar among the options because both of its anomeric carbons are involved in the glycosidic bond, leaving no free reducing group.
  • ➤ Sucrose
  • ➤ non-reducing sugar

questions.text: A new born baby refuses breast milk since 2nd day after birth. She developed diarrhoea on 3rd day, jaundice, hepatomegaly, cataract on 5th day. Urine test for reducing sugar was positive and blood glucose measured by glucose oxidase method was found to be low. The most probable enzyme deficiency associated with above clinical scenario is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic form of Galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase . This disorder leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol, resulting in liver dysfunction , cataracts , and hypoglycemia in newborns after milk ingestion.
  • ➤ The classic form of Galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase . This disorder leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol, resulting in liver dysfunction , cataracts , and hypoglycemia in newborns after milk ingestion.
  • ➤ classic form of Galactosemia
  • ➤ Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase
  • ➤ liver dysfunction
  • ➤ cataracts
  • ➤ hypoglycemia

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic intermediate involved in glycolysis, gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucose 6-phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose 6-phosphate (G6P) is a common metabolic intermediate that is involved in glycolysis , gluconeogenesis , and glycogenolysis . It is essential for energy metabolism and glucose homeostasis.
  • ➤ Glucose 6-phosphate (G6P)
  • ➤ glycolysis
  • ➤ gluconeogenesis
  • ➤ glycogenolysis

questions.text: An infant with corneal clouding has dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate in his urine. Decreased activity of which of the enzymes listed below would confirm the suspected diagnosis of Hurler syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) α-L-Iduronidase complete deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hurler syndrome (MPS I) is caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme α-L-Iduronidase . The classic signs of Hurler syndrome include corneal clouding , hepatomegaly , skeletal abnormalities , and mental retardation . The presence of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate in urine, combined with these clinical features, points specifically to a complete deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase .
  • ➤ Hurler syndrome (MPS I) is caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme α-L-Iduronidase . The classic signs of Hurler syndrome include corneal clouding , hepatomegaly , skeletal abnormalities , and mental retardation .
  • ➤ Hurler syndrome
  • ➤ complete deficiency
  • ➤ α-L-Iduronidase
  • ➤ corneal clouding
  • ➤ hepatomegaly
  • ➤ skeletal abnormalities
  • ➤ mental retardation
  • ➤ The presence of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate in urine, combined with these clinical features, points specifically to a complete deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase .
  • ➤ dermatan sulfate
  • ➤ heparan sulfate
  • ➤ complete deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase

questions.text: Malonyl-CoA, the first intermediate in fatty acid synthesis, is an important reciprocal regulator of fatty acid metabolism because:

options.label: A
options.text: Its formation from acetyl-CoA and bicarbonate by the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the main rate-limiting step in fatty acid synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyl transferase-1.

options.label: C
options.text: It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II.

options.label: D
options.text: It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitine- acylcarnitine translocase.

questions.correct_answer: B. It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyl transferase-1.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyl transferase-1.

questions.text: Inactivation of acetyl-CoA carboxylase is favored when:
questions.correct_answer: C. The tricarboxylate transporter is inhibited.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The tricarboxylate transporter is inhibited.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inactivation of acetyl-CoA carboxylase occurs when the tricarboxylate transporter is inhibited , leading to a decrease in cytosolic citrate levels , which in turn reduces the activation of acetyl-CoA carboxylase. This helps shift metabolism toward fatty acid oxidation instead of synthesis
  • ➤ Inactivation
  • ➤ acetyl-CoA carboxylase
  • ➤ tricarboxylate transporter is inhibited
  • ➤ cytosolic citrate levels
  • ➤ fatty acid oxidation

questions.text: Which one of the following is the major product of fatty acid synthase?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Palmitate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The major product of fatty acid synthase is palmitate (C16:0) , a 16-carbon saturated fatty acid, which is the primary fatty acid produced during de novo fatty acid synthesis.
  • ➤ palmitate (C16:0)

questions.text: Fatty acids are broken down by repeated removal of two carbon fragments as acetyl-CoA in the β-oxidation cycle, and synthesized by repeated condensation of acetyl-CoAs until a long-chain saturated fatty acid with an even number of carbons is formed. Since fatty acids need to be broken down when energy is in short supply and synthesized when it is plentiful, there are important differences between the two processes which help cells to regulate them efficiently. Which one of the following statements concerning these differences is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Fatty acid breakdown takes place inside mitochondria, while synthesis occurs in the cytosol.

options.label: B
options.text: Fatty acid breakdown uses NAD and produces NADH, while synthesis uses NADPH and produces NADP.

options.label: C
options.text: Transport across the mitochondrial membrane of fatty acyl groups is required for fatty acid breakdown, but not for synthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Glucagon promotes fatty acid synthesis and inhibits fatty acid breakdown.

questions.correct_answer: D. Glucagon promotes fatty acid synthesis and inhibits fatty acid breakdown.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glucagon promotes fatty acid synthesis and inhibits fatty acid breakdown.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucagon promotes fatty acid breakdown (β-oxidation) and inhibits fatty acid synthesis , making Option D the incorrect statement.
  • ➤ Glucagon promotes fatty acid breakdown (β-oxidation) and inhibits fatty acid synthesis , making Option D the incorrect statement.
  • ➤ Glucagon
  • ➤ fatty acid breakdown
  • ➤ fatty acid synthesis
  • ➤ Option D
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ 1. Fatty Acid Breakdown (β-oxidation):
  • ➤ 1. Fatty Acid Breakdown (β-oxidation):
  • ➤ Location: Takes place in the mitochondria . Energy production: Involves the removal of two-carbon units from fatty acids as acetyl-CoA , and generates NADH and FADH₂ which are used to produce ATP. Transport requirement: Fatty acyl groups must be transported into the mitochondria, as β-oxidation occurs there. This is facilitated by the carnitine shuttle (via CPT-1 ).
  • ➤ Location: Takes place in the mitochondria .
  • ➤ Location:
  • ➤ mitochondria
  • ➤ Energy production: Involves the removal of two-carbon units from fatty acids as acetyl-CoA , and generates NADH and FADH₂ which are used to produce ATP.
  • ➤ Energy production:
  • ➤ removal of two-carbon units
  • ➤ acetyl-CoA
  • ➤ NADH
  • ➤ FADH₂
  • ➤ Transport requirement: Fatty acyl groups must be transported into the mitochondria, as β-oxidation occurs there. This is facilitated by the carnitine shuttle (via CPT-1 ).
  • ➤ Transport requirement:
  • ➤ carnitine shuttle
  • ➤ CPT-1
  • ➤ 2. Fatty Acid Synthesis:
  • ➤ 2. Fatty Acid Synthesis:
  • ➤ Location: Occurs in the cytosol . Energy input: Acetyl-CoA is condensed to form long-chain fatty acids, requiring NADPH (not NADH) as a reducing agent. Transport requirement: There is no need for fatty acyl groups to be transported into mitochondria for synthesis since this process takes place in the cytosol.
  • ➤ Location: Occurs in the cytosol .
  • ➤ Location:
  • ➤ cytosol
  • ➤ Energy input: Acetyl-CoA is condensed to form long-chain fatty acids, requiring NADPH (not NADH) as a reducing agent.
  • ➤ Energy input:
  • ➤ Acetyl-CoA
  • ➤ NADPH
  • ➤ Transport requirement: There is no need for fatty acyl groups to be transported into mitochondria for synthesis since this process takes place in the cytosol.
  • ➤ Transport requirement:
  • ➤ no need
  • ➤ 3. Hormonal Regulation:
  • ➤ 3. Hormonal Regulation:
  • ➤ Insulin promotes fatty acid synthesis and inhibits fatty acid breakdown (β-oxidation) in the fed state . Glucagon promotes fatty acid breakdown (β-oxidation) and inhibits fatty acid synthesis in the fasting state .
  • ➤ Insulin promotes fatty acid synthesis and inhibits fatty acid breakdown (β-oxidation) in the fed state .
  • ➤ Insulin
  • ➤ fatty acid synthesis
  • ➤ fatty acid breakdown
  • ➤ fed state
  • ➤ Glucagon promotes fatty acid breakdown (β-oxidation) and inhibits fatty acid synthesis in the fasting state .
  • ➤ Glucagon
  • ➤ fatty acid breakdown
  • ➤ fatty acid synthesis
  • ➤ fasting state

questions.text: Which of the plasma lipoproteins is best described as follows: synthesized in the intestinal mucosa, contains a high concentration of triacylglycerol, and is responsible for the transport of dietary lipids in the circulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chylomicrons

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chylomicrons are synthesized in the intestinal mucosa, contain a high concentration of dietary triglycerides, and are responsible for transporting dietary lipids through the circulation to peripheral tissues.

questions.text: Which of the plasma lipoproteins is best described as follows: formed in the circulation by removal of triacylglycerol from very-low-density lipoprotein, contains apo B-100, delivers cholesterol to extrahepatic tissues?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Low-density lipoprotein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is formed from VLDL in the circulation by the removal of triacylglycerol, contains apo B-100, and is responsible for delivering cholesterol to extrahepatic tissues.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with severe hypercholesterolemia has a family history of deaths at a young age from heart disease and stroke. Which of the following genes is likely having decreased function?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The LDL receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A decreased function of the LDL receptor is the most common cause of familial hypercholesterolemia, leading to elevated LDL cholesterol levels and increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: Compounds which inhibit the action of the recently discovered protein, proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9), have been identified as a potential antiatherogenic drugs because PCSK9:

options.label: A
options.text: Decreases the number of LDL receptors exposed at the cell surface, thus LDL uptake is lowered and blood cholesterol levels rise.

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibits the binding of apo B to the LDL receptor, thus blocking uptake of the lipoprotein and raising blood cholesterol levels.

options.label: C
options.text: Increases the absorption of cholesterol from the intestine.

options.label: D
options.text: Increases the synthesis and secretion of VLDL in the liver, leading to increased LDL. formation in the blood.

questions.correct_answer: A. Decreases the number of LDL receptors exposed at the cell surface, thus LDL uptake is lowered and blood cholesterol levels rise.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Decreases the number of LDL receptors exposed at the cell surface, thus LDL uptake is lowered and blood cholesterol levels rise.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibition of PCSK9 prevents the degradation of LDL receptors, increasing their availability on the liver surface. This enhances LDL cholesterol clearance from the blood, reducing cholesterol levels and providing a cardioprotective effect.

questions.text: Cardiolipin is a Phospholipid which is antigenic, defect in cardiolipin synthesis lead to Barth syndrome in which patient presents with cardiomyopathy it is present in? ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inner Mitochondrial Membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiolipin is a phospholipid localized to the inner mitochondrial membrane , essential for mitochondrial function and stability. Defects in its synthesis or remodeling are linked to Barth syndrome , a disorder characterized by cardiomyopathy.
  • ➤ inner mitochondrial membrane
  • ➤ Barth syndrome

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Very Long chain fatty acid
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Very Long chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Zellweger syndrome, a functional deficiency of peroxisomes leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids due to defective beta-oxidation. This accumulation is a key pathological hallmark of the disease, contributing to its severe neurological symptoms.
  • ➤ functional deficiency of peroxisomes
  • ➤ very long chain fatty acids

questions.text: The reaction: succinyl CoA + acetoacetate → Acetoacetyl CoA + succinate occurs in all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Liver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The liver synthesizes ketone bodies but does not utilize them due to the absence of thiophorase . This enzyme is essential for ketone body utilization, which occurs in tissues like the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.
  • ➤ thiophorase

questions.text: Tangier disease is autosomal recessive disease characterized by orange tonsil and low HDL. It is due to mutation in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ABCA1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tangier disease is characterized by low HDL levels and orange tonsils due to mutations in the ABCA1 gene , which impairs cholesterol efflux and reverse cholesterol transport.
  • ➤ low HDL levels
  • ➤ orange tonsils
  • ➤ ABCA1 gene

questions.text: A child present with pancytopenia, neck rigidity, hypertonia, fatal bronchopneumonia. Bone marrow biopsy result shows ‘crumbled tissue paper appearance’ because of accumulation of
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucocerebroside

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaucher disease is caused by a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase , leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside , which results in the characteristic "crumbled tissue paper" appearance of macrophages in bone marrow.
  • ➤ glucocerebrosidase
  • ➤ glucocerebroside
  • ➤ "crumbled tissue paper" appearance
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: Niemann-Pick disease, like other neurolipidoses, present in infancy or childhood with plateauing of development and neurologic regression. The accumulating substance is a phospholipid made in which of the following steps in the figure below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Step C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Niemann-Pick disease, the accumulation of sphingomyelin occurs due to a deficiency of sphingomyelinase . The synthesis of sphingomyelin occurs in Step C of the pathway.
  • ➤ sphingomyelin
  • ➤ sphingomyelinase
  • ➤ Step C

questions.text: Identify the marked bond:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The marked bond between adenine and thymine in DNA is a hydrogen bond , essential for base-pairing and stability of the DNA double helix.
  • ➤ marked bond
  • ➤ hydrogen bond

questions.text: The backbone of a DNA molecule consists of which of the following?
questions.correct_answer: D. Alternating phosphate and sugar groups
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Alternating phosphate and sugar groups

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The backbone of DNA is made of alternating phosphate and sugar groups , linked by phosphodiester bonds , which provide structural stability to the molecule.
  • ➤ backbone of DNA
  • ➤ alternating phosphate and sugar groups
  • ➤ phosphodiester bonds

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in polymerase chain reaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dideoxyribonucleotides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dideoxyribonucleotides are not used in PCR because they terminate DNA synthesis. Instead, they are used in Sanger sequencing for DNA sequence determination.
  • ➤ Dideoxyribonucleotides are not used in PCR

questions.text: If a tRNA has the sequence 5'-CAU-3′, what codon would it recognize (ignore wobble base pairing).
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 5'-AUG-3’

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anticodon 5'-CAU-3' in tRNA recognizes the complementary codon 5'-AUG-3' on mRNA, following base-pairing rules and anti-parallel orientation.
  • ➤ anticodon 5'-CAU-3'
  • ➤ 5'-AUG-3'

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis explains which of the following concepts of the genetic code?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Degeneracy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The wobble hypothesis explains the degeneracy of the genetic code, which allows one tRNA to recognize multiple codons due to flexibility in base pairing at the third position of the codon.
  • ➤ wobble hypothesis
  • ➤ degeneracy

questions.text: Most aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases possess an activity that is shared with DNA polymerases. This activity is a _________ function.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proofreading

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases and DNA polymerases share a proofreading function , ensuring accuracy by detecting and correcting errors in their respective processes: tRNA charging and DNA replication.
  • ➤ proofreading function

questions.text: The initiator tRNA is placed within the active 80S complex at which of the three-canonical ribosomal "sites" during protein synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) P site

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initiator tRNA carrying methionine is positioned at the P site during the initiation of protein synthesis in the active 80S ribosome.
  • ➤ initiator tRNA
  • ➤ P site

questions.text: Name the enzyme that forms the peptide bond during protein synthesis and define its chemical composition.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Peptidyl transferase, RNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peptidyl transferase , an enzyme composed of ribosomal RNA , catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds during protein synthesis. It is a key example of a ribozyme.
  • ➤ Peptidyl transferase
  • ➤ ribosomal RNA

questions.text: Which of the following histone amino acids are typically acetylated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lysine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lysine residues in histone proteins are typically acetylated , leading to chromatin relaxation and transcriptional activation. This process is crucial for regulating gene expression.
  • ➤ Lysine residues in histone proteins are typically acetylated

questions.text: All but one of the following histones are found located within the superhelix formed between DNA and the histone octamer; which of the following is this histone?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Histone H1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histone H1 is not part of the histone octamer; it is located outside the nucleosome, where it binds to linker DNA and plays a role in chromatin stabilization and higher-order folding.
  • ➤ Histone H1

questions.text: Which of the following hypothesizes that the physical and functional status of a certain region of genomic chromatin is dependent on the patterns of specific histone post translational modifications (PTMs), and/or DNA methylation status?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epigenetic code

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The epigenetic code hypothesis explains how patterns of histone modifications and DNA methylation regulate the structural and functional status of chromatin, influencing gene expression without altering the DNA sequence.
  • ➤ epigenetic code

questions.text: Given below is a diagrammatic representation of karyotype of an individual. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Angelman syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The deletion of the maternal allele in chromosome 15 results in Angelman syndrome , while the deletion of the paternal allele leads to Prader-Willi syndrome . Mothers are associated with Angelman (M for maternal), and Paternal deletions cause Prader-Willi (P for paternal).
  • ➤ deletion of the maternal allele in chromosome 15
  • ➤ Angelman syndrome
  • ➤ Prader-Willi syndrome

questions.text: RNAi or dsRNA-mediated RNA interference mediates which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RNA silencing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RNA interference (RNAi) mediates RNA silencing by degrading or inhibiting the translation of target mRNA, effectively silencing gene expression. This process is a vital post-transcriptional regulatory mechanism in cells
  • ➤ RNA interference (RNAi)
  • ➤ RNA silencing

questions.text: Which of the following is the name of a common organometallic DNA-binding motif?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zinc finger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The zinc finger motif is a critical organometallic DNA-binding structure found in many proteins that regulate gene expression. It enables these proteins to interact with DNA in a highly specific manner.
  • ➤ zinc finger motif

questions.text: A child presents with hyperuricemia and delayed developmental milestones. He also has the habit of biting fingers and nails. What is the most probable enzyme deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HGPRtase deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a deficiency in HGPRTase , leading to hyperuricemia , neurological symptoms, and self-mutilation behaviors. This condition is a hallmark of purine metabolism disorders.
  • ➤ HGPRTase
  • ➤ hyperuricemia

questions.text: All of the following cell types contain the enzyme telomerase which protects the length of telomerase at the end of chromosomes, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Somatic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telomerase is active in germinal, hemopoietic, and tumor cells but is absent in somatic cells , where telomere shortening contributes to aging and cellular senescence.
  • ➤ germinal, hemopoietic, and tumor cells
  • ➤ somatic cells

questions.text: Which enzyme prevents aging?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Telomerase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telomerase prevents aging by maintaining telomere length, which preserves chromosomal stability and delays cellular senescence.
  • ➤ Telomerase

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the coding for transcription has the base sequence GATCTAC. What is the base sequence of RNA product?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) GAUCUAC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The RNA sequence matches the coding strand of DNA except that T is replaced by U , making the RNA sequence GAUCUAC in this case.
  • ➤ coding strand
  • ➤ T is replaced by U
  • ➤ GAUCUAC

questions.text: Restriction enzymes are used to cleave genomic DNA into smaller fragments. Which of the following DNA sequences has the best potential to be a site of action for a restriction endonuclease? ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) C–T–G–C–A–G

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Restriction enzymes recognize and cleave palindromic sequences in double-stranded DNA. The sequence C–T–G–C–A–G matches this criterion, making it the best candidate for restriction enzyme cleavage.
  • ➤ palindromic sequences
  • ➤ C–T–G–C–A–G

questions.text: A child develops blisters on exposure to sunlight. Irregular dark spots on the skin are also found which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is defective?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nucleotide Excision Repair.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Xeroderma pigmentosum is caused by a defect in nucleotide excision repair, leading to an inability to repair UV-induced thymine dimers, which results in photosensitivity, skin blistering, and a predisposition to skin cancer.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5'→3' Exonuclease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Klenow fragment is a version of DNA polymerase I that lacks the 5'→3' exonuclease activity but retains both 5'→3' polymerase and 3'→5' exonuclease activities. It is widely used in molecular biology for DNA synthesis and sequencing.

questions.text: On which one of the following coagulation factors does a patient taking warfarin for his thrombotic disorder have decreased γ-carboxyglutamate residues?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Factor II (prothrombin)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, reducing the γ-carboxylation of vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors (II, VII, IX, and X). This leads to decreased activity of these factors, including prothrombin (factor II), essential for clot formation.

questions.text: 30-year-old man presented at clinic with a history of intermittent abdominal pain and episodes of confusion and psychiatric problems. Laboratory tests revealed increases of urinary δ-aminolevulinate and porphobilinogen. Mutational analysis revealed a mutation in the gene for uroporphyrinogen I synthase (porphobilinogen deaminase). The probable diagnosis was:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute intermittent porphyria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute intermittent porphyria is characterized by episodes of severe abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and increased urinary δ-aminolevulinate and porphobilinogen. It is caused by a defect in uroporphyrinogen I synthase, also known as porphobilinogen deaminase.

questions.text: A baby is hypotonic and shows increased ratio of Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Pyruvate cannot form Acetyl CoA in fibroblast. He also shows features of lactic acidosis. Which of the following can revert the situation? ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thiamin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiamin (vitamin B1) is a crucial cofactor for the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex. Its deficiency or dysfunction of the enzyme leads to lactic acidosis. Supplementing thiamin can help restore the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, reducing lactate accumulation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old bodybuilder has decided to go on a diet consisting of only egg whites to ensure optimal protein for muscle growth. After a few weeks, he notices decreased energy and is found to be hypoglycemic. A nutritionist tells the patient that he most likely has a functional biotin deficiency. Which of the following enzymes is unable to catalyze a key step in synthesizing glucose from pyruvate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyruvate carboxylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyruvate carboxylase is a biotin-dependent enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, an essential step in gluconeogenesis. Biotin deficiency, often caused by excessive raw egg white consumption, impairs this enzyme, leading to hypoglycemia and decreased energy levels.

questions.text: A 15-month-old female child whose growth rate has been in the low over the last year presents with chronic, nonproductive cough for which she was prescribed antibiotics and taking for long time patient has diarrhea with foul-smelling stools. She is diagnosed as having cystic fibrosis. For which of the following vitamins is this child most likely to be at risk of deficiency? ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis impairs fat absorption, leading to deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). Prolonged antibiotic use can further reduce vitamin K levels by disrupting the gut flora, increasing the risk of vitamin K deficiency.

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency lead to decreased energy production because ​​​​​​​

options.label: A
options.text: Thiamine (TPP) interfere with energy production from amino acids

options.label: B
options.text: TPP act as cofactor for transketolase activity

options.label: D
options.text: Thiamine act as cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

questions.correct_answer: D. Thiamine act as cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thiamine act as cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiamine (TPP) is a critical cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, both of which are essential for ATP production in the citric acid cycle. Thiamine deficiency impairs these enzymes, reducing energy production.

questions.text: Identify the type of enzyme inhibiton
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Competitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The graph shows the hallmark of competitive inhibition, where the lines intersect on the y-axis, indicating that the inhibitor increases Km without affecting Vmax.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding oxygenase except:
questions.correct_answer: D. Required for carboxylation of drugs.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Required for carboxylation of drugs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxygenases are involved in the incorporation of oxygen into substrates (as hydroxylation or oxidation), but they are not responsible for carboxylation reactions, which are catalyzed by carboxylases.

questions.text: Keshan disease is disease caused by deficiency of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Selenium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keshan disease is a selenium deficiency-related cardiomyopathy, highlighting the importance of selenium in protecting the heart from oxidative damage.

questions.text: Which of the following are Methanol poisoning derivatives?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Formic acid+ Lactic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methanol poisoning results in the accumulation of formic acid and lactic acid, causing metabolic acidosis and potentially severe toxic effects.

questions.text: Velocity at Km is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Half the V max.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At Km, the velocity of an enzymatic reaction is half of the maximum velocity (Vmax).

questions.text: A Buffer that is most effective at pH of about 6.1 is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bicarbonate Buffer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bicarbonate buffer is most effective at a pH of 6.1, aligning with its pKa, and plays a critical role in maintaining physiological pH.

questions.text: Digestive enzymes are?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hydrolases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Digestive enzymes, including amylase, lipase, and proteases, belong to the hydrolase class and function by breaking down macromolecules into smaller absorbable units through hydrolysis.

questions.text: Tyrosinase is a?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tyrosinase is an oxidase enzyme crucial for melanin synthesis and requires copper as a co-factor for its activity.

questions.text: The patient had a history of strenous exercise but forgot to take his meal and later had alcohol in a party. Which of the following process is inhibited by alcohol
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gluconeogenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcohol inhibits gluconeogenesis by increasing NADH levels, which depletes oxaloacetate and pyruvate, leading to potential hypoglycemia in fasting states.
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Chronic alcohol consumption leads to thiamine deficiency because alcohol inhibits its absorption and metabolism.
  • ➤ thiamine deficiency
  • ➤ Thiamine is essential for carbohydrate metabolism, and its deficiency is the primary cause of complications in alcoholics.
  • ➤ Thiamine
  • ➤ Treatment for alcohol-related disorders involves thiamine supplementation:
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy : Acute condition treated with high-dose intravenous thiamine. Korsakoff's psychosis : Chronic condition managed with oral thiamine. Alcohol withdrawal : Always treat with thiamine to prevent complications.
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy : Acute condition treated with high-dose intravenous thiamine.
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy
  • ➤ Korsakoff's psychosis : Chronic condition managed with oral thiamine.
  • ➤ Korsakoff's psychosis
  • ➤ Alcohol withdrawal : Always treat with thiamine to prevent complications.
  • ➤ Alcohol withdrawal
  • ➤ Advice for alcohol consumers: Supplement with thiamine to mitigate deficiency-related complications.
  • ➤ Thiamine should be given before dextrose to prevent worsening of thiamine deficiency and associated complications.
  • ➤ Thiamine should be given before dextrose to prevent worsening of thiamine deficiency and associated complications.
  • ➤ before dextrose

questions.text: In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme. After 9 minutes of reaction, 1% of substrate is converted to product (12 microgram/ml). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and concentration of substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into the same amount of product that i.e. 12 microgram/ml?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 27 minutes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under zero-order kinetics, the reaction rate depends only on enzyme concentration and not substrate concentration when the substrate is in excess. Reducing enzyme concentration increases the time required proportionally.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman who recently lost her job because of absenteeism, presents to her physician complaining of loss of appetite, fatigue, muscle weakness, and emotional depression. The physical examination reveals a somewhat enlarged liver that feels firm and nodular, and there is a hint of jaundice in the sclerae and a hint of alcohol on her breath. The initial laboratory profile included a hematological analysis that showed that she had an anemia with enlarged red blood cells (macrocytic). A bone marrow aspirate confirmed the suspicion that she has a megaloblastic anemia because it showed a greater than normal number of red and white blood cell precursors, most of which were larger than normal. Further analyses revealed that her serum folic acid level was 2.9 ng/mL (normal = 6 to 15), her serum B12 level was 153 pg/mL (normal = 150 to 750), and her serum iron level was normal. The patient’s megaloblastic anemia is most likely caused by which of the following? ​​​​​​​

options.label: B
options.text: A decreased conversion of dUMP to dTMP

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in the synthesis of phosphatidyl choline

options.label: D
options.text: A decrease in the levels of succinyl CoA

questions.correct_answer: B. A decreased conversion of dUMP to dTMP
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A decreased conversion of dUMP to dTMP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folic acid deficiency leads to impaired conversion of dUMP to dTMP, causing defective DNA synthesis and megaloblastic anemia, characterized by large, immature red blood cells.
